document.title: 2021 Minnesota K12 Academic Standards in Social Studies Final

CFA119A6D54244B98BDC8DBF79639CF8.description: Examine the impact of slavery and race in Minnesota today.

46EBBE9EAF994BE89663754F9FDDCF04.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

5978BE99B5404F39AEBBCBDB2CA28A01.description:
Identify how the arts have been a part of strategies, activities
and/or engagement for social and political change.

6CAD13FC496A478281D7F64963012D84.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

BED39E77D955424F8A44726686ECD449.description:
Identify individuals, community organizations, businesses and
corporations that make the student’s community in Minnesota
unique. Analyze how these groups do community building
efforts, specifically by racialized and marginalized
groups/individuals in Minnesota.

4ED7A53AB26847C7A621DC3E77CC904F.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

AD5D3756948D4094AAFF90DAD26D3284.description:
Examine how and why the Minnesota landscape has been
shaped by people.

516C150D05534658B6B06937F4CDB21D.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

6453331F27F143C3960A19148ABAA94F.description:
Identify and explain how discrimination based on race, gender,
economic, ableism, and social group identity affects the history,
health, growth, and/or current experiences of residents of
Minnesota.

80108FF14AE347ADB13FA616CE66DDBC.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

3C653A4050FF4DC0A890B0C6B9F93075.description:
Identify and describe how Minnesotans have fought for
freedom and equality from the Civil Rights era until today.

A22FD31495BC4617AF283814478F2FA3.description:
Connecting Past and Present:
Use historical methods and
sources to identify and analyze
the roots of a contemporary
issue. Design a plan to address it.

B207151210024883BE51A9D7EF8603F8.description:
Examine the history and memory of migration and immigration
in Minnesota during the late 19th and early 20th centuries,
including the impact of immigration on Indigenous people.

9ED6411E0FF54B62BD456AF523F09D2B.description:
Connecting Past and Present:
Use historical methods and
sources to identify and analyze
the roots of a contemporary
issue. Design a plan to address it.

375709059A934AC6B5A6AE5469CF5E50.description:
Examine the historical relationship and memorialization of the
U.S. Civil War and the U.S.-Dakota War of 1862 in Minnesota.

D483BD9077A74E939C1DF05C1A853C0C.description:
Connecting Past and Present:
Use historical methods and
sources to identify and analyze
the roots of a contemporary
issue. Design a plan to address it.

8A808017C0114D0688DD2803769C6BBF.description:
Construct a narrative about why and how people have migrated
to Minnesota as a result of warfare and/or genocide since 1960,
using primary sources about immigrant experiences.

DBAF51CFED404B88BFE31CA6D829730C.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

B0960C0C7AF14C0FB91C5B3B1D4FC4D6.description:
Evaluate the impact of big business, industrialization, farming
and/or technology on the use of natural resources within
different communities in Minnesota. Organize applicable
evidence into a coherent argument about the past.

D815A57955CC495B88E372E45B02BA74.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

6844383EBC3C4B7A8FFDDE109D8914C4.description:
Evaluate primary and secondary sources about the process by
which Minnesota became a territory and state; consider what
perspectives and narratives are absent from the available
sources.

C72571FF09DB4B0D9F906D74E23568B0.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

272398AD21CF449199EA1D5DE98C04D0.description:
Examine conflicting narratives about the United States-Dakota
War of 1862. Analyze the perspectives of settlers and Dakota
people before, during and after the war. Identify the narratives
that are absent.

1AED95558E004273A67F94A35C940FE6.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

F4FC73287A4F4D469DB837934707AC76.description:
Identify and describe diverse and conflicting points of view
about treaty-making, including the unequal power dynamics
that shaped the treaty-making process.

FA9C0387DD1A4EE1A46304A6C8EC32FC.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

8DDB538DB9AA400EA2D5B8DB32C3AF5C.description:
Understand the diverse and conflicting ways that Dakota,
Anishinaabe, European and American peoples understood their
relationship to the land, particularly regarding property and
ownership, and examine the consequences of these conflicting
views on the environment over time.

F9E41518A23941BABBAE7413FF7E6285.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

99AE37C16BF14D47A3FAC0E329633010.description:
Identify multiple narratives about how World War II and the
Cold War impacted Minnesotans.

1C44A7039B8F46E085F16FEBB23ECAE9.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

256BD285E6B542058802BBE0C6D860A3.description:
Analyze connections between major reform and political
movements in Minnesota during the Progressive era and World
War I, including the role of women.

06D84C4E63C2431DBDCD9EFBB0B8CE94.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

EC049CCB0EF24FF682898F49AEEE47A2.description:
Describe how people in Minnesota participated in the
institution of slavery, abolition and the U.S. Civil War,
identifying examples of change and continuity.

BE18C18552C240C29A4595AD41EB027D.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

12A0D35C430344A4A9B425FD9B720DB2.description:
Describe the varied and diverse interactions of Indigenous
people, European/American traders and settler-colonists in the
upper Mississippi River region, and examine how settler
colonialism conflicted with Dakota and Anishinaabe ways of life.

A822F9BB179C40F7882CBEE05722721B.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

B70D15219E2F4BE081297361B934B0A8.description:
Describe how Dakota and Anishinaabe people today narrate
their own history, including seasonal lifeways in the pre-contact
period.

3A0F9ABA45184FB7884D8532E1CB2DE3.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

CFA7E4A7C6EC4CDC9325E4FAA001AD12.description:
Evaluate how two (or more) different communities address the
issues related to climate change in Minnesota.

D54F58E43440456EACEDB8DC2DE2F2E8.description:
Human-Environment
Interaction: Evaluate the
relationship between humans
and the environment, including
climate change.

33A81C7D01684C83968D6F617B34F5DB.description:
Explain how physical features and the location of resources
affect settlement patterns, including those of Dakota and
Anishinaabe peoples, and the growth of cities.

4FFAE356EFEE4ABBAF5EECF85BD02F30.description:
Human Systems: Analyze
patterns of movement and
interconnectedness within and
between cultural, economic and
political systems from a local to
global scale.

9774F97026DC47389B7148DC5F7AADF5.description:
Compare and contrast different places and regions on the land
that is Minnesota today, including how power structures have
impacted each one over time.

DEED22FC86424207B04E7824560CF088.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

231178E0A0064E5B87A4C8E340B53233.description:
Use geographic tools to support a claim with evidence and
explain reasoning to address a spatial problem within
Minnesota.

EE4C86F0B5784B0E87A04A7E2ED176DE.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

B3043F5028374B8EB65F1FB040B4F2FC.description:
Use geospatial technologies to create and interpret fixed and
dynamic maps that represent Mni Sóta Maḳoce and Minnesota.

511712570A904C83A12FEC06B1D22455.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

00EEF80CC14040ACA7EADC3119922A65.description:
Explain why companies might move production to other states
or countries.

9C5CA2A48C9E4C1DBC0A49629CD29F32.description:
Global and International:
Explain why people trade and
why nations encourage or limit
trade. Analyze the costs and
benefits of international trade
and globalization on communities
and the environment.

7B7D3370A4DB45418F48702F46AE5DF7.description:
Explain how people living in a community are impacted by
government policies regarding land use. Investigate how
communities are impacted when consumers have or do not
have opportunities to work, shop, eat and connect with one
another locally, helping the community build assets.

D95F968992824F188DA580049B73B40F.description:
Macroeconomics: Measure
and evaluate the well-being of
nations and communities using a
variety of indicators. Explain the
causes of economic ups and
downs. Evaluate how
government actions affect a
nation’s economy and
individuals’ well-being within an
economy.

626C60F8814947A6976570DC5065429C.description:
Describe the movement of goods and services, resources and
money through markets at the community, national and global
level.

5E415AD810CC4777ACFBC49B26FE0C6D.description:
Macroeconomics: Measure
and evaluate the well-being of
nations and communities using a
variety of indicators. Explain the
causes of economic ups and
downs. Evaluate how
government actions affect a
nation’s economy and
individuals’ well-being within an
economy.

BD55AD6F08AC41668D0E239C44805A30.description:
Describe various types of income. Explain the role that the
development of human capital plays in determining one’s
income. Create a budget based on a given monthly income.

463541E734684EF3B12F1341BE23D5AF.description:
Personal Finance: Apply
economic concepts and models
to develop individual and
collective financial goals and
strategies for achieving these
goals, taking into consideration
historical and contemporary
conditions that either inhibit or
advance the creation of individual
and generational wealth.

020BFBD78A6F4AA4A671128C9BBE1264.description:
Explain the concept of sovereignty and how treaty rights are
exercised by the Anishinaabe and Dakota today.

3365549A48C343139A425543170E96A1.description:
Tribal Nations: Evaluate the
unique political status, trust
relationships and governing
structures of sovereign Tribal
Nations and the United States.

A6225963EE914440B411BFA2E88CE885.description:
Describe the goals, offenses, penalties, long-term consequences
and privacy concerns of Minnesota’s juvenile justice system and
evaluate the impact on youth, including those from historically
disenfranchised groups.

1C2212D1D16C4B829AA5555F86B45141.description:
Governmental Institutions and
Political Processes: Explain and
evaluate processes, rules and
laws of United States
governmental institutions at
local, state and federal levels and
within Tribal Nations.

4AB64A9A32CB49BDA3D4B43F56338AE4.description:
Identify the purpose of the Constitution of the State of
Minnesota and explain how the Constitution of the State of
Minnesota organizes state government and authorizes local
government (county, city, school board and township).
Compare and contrast the ways state and local government are
funded.

80A029ED473C40E1A11B79DF5CD644AE.description:
Governmental Institutions and
Political Processes: Explain and
evaluate processes, rules and
laws of United States
governmental institutions at
local, state and federal levels and
within Tribal Nations.

D2E37F1A1B7D414DAC2161AD7AC0C784.description:
Summarize the concept of citizenship in the United States,
explain how individuals become citizens by birth or
naturalization, and compare and contrast the rights and
responsibilities of citizens, noncitizens and dual citizens.

9BA3A77FC6C940C18D6150C8A1AD0037.description:
Rights and Responsibilities:
Explain and evaluate rights,
duties and responsibilities in
democratic society.

BF410657F26F49AE8A238E986FA6FE46.description:
Locate a democratic principle embodied in the Constitution of
the State of Minnesota or in one of Minnesota’s Tribal Nations’
constitutions. Summarize the concept of federalism and
describe the relationship between the powers of the federal
and state governments.

DDC501C4931947F5A7BA7068FAE3EA6B.description:
Democratic Values and
Principles: Explain democratic
values and principles that guide
governments, societies and
communities. Analyze the
tensions within the United States
constitutional government.

49A06C67B6F143CEA2E2EEDA9C8C82CA.description:
Analyze a state or local policy issue by identifying and
examining opposing positions from diverse perspectives and
frames of reference, interpreting and applying graphic data,
determining conflicting values and beliefs, defending and
justifying a position with evidence, and developing strategies to
persuade others to adopt this position.

578F48DB5F7E42148EB62B3E6B0647E6.description:
Civic Skills: Apply civic
reasoning and demonstrate civic
skills for the purpose of informed
and engaged lifelong civic
participation.
